LineItemTitle.val: Amphibious Combat Vehicle Family of Vehicles

Description.val:
The Amphibious Combat Vehicle (ACV) will replace the legacy Assault Amphibious Vehicle (AAV) in the Assault Amphibious (AA) battalions within the Marine Divisions. ACV-equipped AA companies will provide protected mobility and general support lift to elements of Marine Infantry battalions. The ACV, an advanced generation, eight-wheeled armored personnel carrier, will mitigate current and projected capability gaps by providing improved lethality against dismounted enemy troops, more effective land and water tactical mobility, and increased force protection and survivability from blasts, fragmentation, and kinetic energy threats.

In an Acquisition Decision Memorandum (ADM) dated 8 Jan 2019, ASN(RD&A), the Milestone Decision Authority, combined the ACV 1.1 and ACV 1.2 programs into a single ACV Family of Vehicles (FOV) that continues the established phased development and procurement approach. This approach allows the Marine Corps to procure a modernized assault amphibian to serve as the platform to perform missions across the range of military operations to include joint forcible entry operations. 

The initial ACV Increment (FY2018 - FY2021) Personnel variant will deliver combat ready Marines from ship-to-shore in order to mass forces at littoral penetration points and continue to maneuver onward to inland objectives. Subsequent procurements (FY2022 - FY2025) are planned to expand the personnel carrier quantities and to procure command and control, improved lethality, and tactical recovery capabilities.   In an ADM dated 12 July 2019, ASN(RD&A) authorized a third lot of LRIP consisting of 56 vehicles and directed that acquisition documentation reflecting this change shall be updated as part of the Full Rate Production (FRP) Milestone decision approval process.  The first lot of full rate production will be procured in FY 2021.  The merger and additional lot of LRIP are updates from the FY 2020 acquisition strategy.

Justification.val:
FY 2019:  $166.522M 
Funds used to procure Lot 2 (LRIP) of 30 vehicles, plus procurement of related items such as production support, systems engineering/program management, Engineering Change Orders (ECOs), Government Furnished Equipment (GFE), and integrated logistics support. 

FY 2020:  $300.935M
Funds procure Lot 3 (LRIP) of 56 vehicles, plus procurement of related items such as production support, systems engineering/program management, Engineering Change Orders (ECOs), Government Furnished Equipment (GFE), and integrated logistics support.  

FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation Request: $478.874M
Funds will procure Lot 4, first Full Rate Production (FRP) lot of 72 vehicles, plus procurement of related items such as production support, systems engineering/program management, Engineering Change Orders (ECOs), Government Furnished Equipment (GFE), and integrated logistics support. Net increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $177.939M primarily due to the procurement and support of 16 additional vehicles in FY2021 and prime contactor foreign currency exchange costs and royalties to suppliers per the terms and conditions of the negotiated contract.

Production was adjusted in FY 2021 from 92 vehicles to 72 vehicles to allow for a more gradual production ramp and to pay for increased costs of design labor for Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), production and installation of ECPs, vehicle refurbishment following IOT&E, and increased logistics and support costs.

The increase in cost between FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $56.654 is primarily attributed to the increase in FY 2021 for an additional sixteen (16) vehicles to continue the production ramp-up to Full Rate Production.  Lots 1-4 (FY 2018 - FY 2021) procure ACV-P variants only. Name.@footnote: GFE Communication Suites procurement includes tactical radios (2 AN/VRC-114V2 systems comprised of 4 PRC-117G radios and 4 antennas for each vehicle), Battlefield Command & Control Situational Awareness (currently via the Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P)), and satellite communications (via the Mobile User Objective System (MUOS) Diplexer).  The increase in Communications Suites between FY2020 and FY2021 of $5.102 is attributed to the increase of sixteen (16) vehicles in FY2021.

GFE Remote Weapons Station (RWS) procurement includes the Mk-153 Common Remotely Operated Weapon Station, which consists of a single-mount weapons station and weapon (either an M2 0.50cal heavy machine gun or a Mk-19 40mm automatic grenade launcher), Main Processing Unit (MPU), Display and Control Panel (DCP), Control Grip, Laser Range Finder (LRF), Thermal camera system (TIM), Day camera system (VIM), Sight Servo Assembly (SSA) system, and Main Frame Assembly (MFA).  The increase in RWS between FY2020 and FY2021 of $19.106 is attributed to the change in the acquisition strategy for RWS.  Prior to FY2021, the program acquired existing RWS systems from the Army and refurbished these systems with parts and components in order to bring them to a configuration suitable for ACV.  For FY2021 and beyond, the program is procuring new RWS systems because no additional RWS systems remain from the Army.

Name.@footnote: Systems Engineering/Program Management (SE/PM) is a recurring charge from the Prime Contractor. Recurring systems engineering includes the costs of maintainability/reliability engineering, maintenance engineering, value engineering, production engineering costs associated with the system, periodic system design/evaluation, and analysis of test results during production. Recurring program management includes the overall planning, direction, and control of the definition, development, and production of the system/program, including the functions of business management. Net increase between FY2020 to FY2021 of $1.951 primarily based on the contract cost in accordance with the awarded fixed price incentive contract. All terms were competitively-derived, negotiated, and accepted by the Government.

The increase in vehicle modifications between FY2020 and FY2021 of $15.000 is attributed to initiation of the refurbishment of twenty-six (26) LRIP Lot 1 vehicles which were utilized during conduct of Initial Operational Test & Evaluation (IOT&E).  These vehicles must be reconditioned prior to fielding to operational units following the completion of IOT&E.

Engineering Change Orders (ECOs) address fact of life changes to vehicle configuration such as performance, safety, or reliability.  The increase in ECO between FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $15.269 is attributed to anticipated ECOs resulting from the ACV Logistics Demonstration for Conditioned-based Maintenance, maintenance access panels and test ports, fuel/hydraulic/water/bilge line markings, and captive fasteners.  The purpose and intent of the Logistics Demonstration was to evaluate the supportability of the materiel design, determine adequacy of maintenance planning, evaluate Technical Publications content (Operator, Operator Maintenance, and Organizational Maintenance Tasks), evaluate suitability and availability of maintenance training devices, evaluate suitability and availability of Test Measurement and Diagnostic Equipment (TMDE), evaluate Maintenance Allocation Chart (MAC) content, and evaluate adequacy of the Repair Parts and Special Tools List (RPSTL).  Changes resulting to the vehicle from the Logistics Demonstration make the system more supportable.

The increase in Nonrecurring Engineering and Industrial Tooling between FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $4.261 reflects procurement of additional production tooling to facilitate an increase in production throughput and a nonrecurring charge to support process development for standard depot-level maintenance.
The increase in Production Support from FY2020 to FY2021 of $2.228 is attributed to program office support requirements transitioning from development to the procurement appropriation.

Acceptance Testing provides effort/materials associated with tests that are conducted to determine if the requirements and the specifications of the vehicle and/or contract are met.  It is funded in the fiscal year in which the item is procured as part of the full funding policy.  The increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $0.437 is based on the contract cost in accordance with the awarded fixed price incentive contract.  All terms were competitively-derived, negotiated, and accepted by the Government.

Peculiar Training Equipment and Simulators represents the procurement of operator and maintenance trainers essential to conducting training prior to system fielding. The increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $5.565 is attributed to procurement of Operator and Maintainer training devices and Command-variant communication training systems in FY2021.

The increase in Pubs and Tech Data between FY2020 and FY2021 of $4.551 is attributed to procurement of updates to technical manuals, and procurement of the technical data package from the prime contractor per the terms and conditions of the contract.

Support equipment are devices required to inspect, test, service, adjust, calibrate, measure, repair, overhaul, assemble, disassemble, handle, store, or otherwise support the lifecycle management of the ACV. The increase from FY2020 to FY2021 of $1.741 is due to the procurement of shipping containers for the Remote Weapon Stations.

ILS includes Logistics Management Information (LMI) procurement and platform support products necessary for the planning and preparation to support the fielded system until organic support capability is established. This effort will enable a journeyman level repair technician(s) to disassemble, clean, inspect, overhaul/rebuild, repair/refurbish, reassemble and test, at a Government Depot, all secondary repairables identified by the Contractor during its Supportability Analyses and Level of Repair Analyses and documented in the LMI data tracking system. The cost is based on the contract cost in accordance with the awarded fixed price incentive contract. All terms were negotiated and accepted by the Government. The increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $46.074 is primarily attributed to award of prime contractor total package fielding effort, and prime contractor foreign currency exchange costs and royalties to suppliers negotiated under the terms and conditions of the prime contract. The first four lots of ACV production were negotiated and priced under these foreign exchange and royalty terms, which were determined to be a fair and reasonable pricing mechanism to allow the prime contractor to establish firm pricing option on the first four lots of production (FY18-FY21).  This pricing mechanism was reviewed and vetted by the MDA and NCCA at Milestone C and was implemented to protect the government from annual foreign currency fluctuations. BAE is the prime contractor and IVECO Defense is the main supplier.
